{{also|Alt|alt-|atl|√°lt|√°lt.}} ==English== ===Pronunciation=== * {{rhymes|en|…îÀêlt}} ===Etymology 1=== From {{bor|en|la|altus}}. ====Noun==== {{en-noun|-}} # {{lb|en|music}} High [[pitch]], of a voice or instrument; especially, the octave above the top line of the [[treble]] stave. {{defdate|from 16th c.}} #* {{quote-book|en|title=The Musical Lady|author=[[w:George Colman the Elder|George Colman]]|year=1762|passage=Sop[hy] Moderato! moderato! Madam. Your Ladyship's absolutely in '''alt'''. / L[ady] Scr[ape] In '''alt'''! Madam? / Sop[hy] Yes, in '''alt'''- Give me leave to tell your Ladyship, that you have raised your voice a full octave higher since you came into the room.}} #* {{quote-book|en|title=Ellen, Countess of Castle Howel: A Novel|volume=1|author=Mrs. Bennett (Agnes Maria)|year=1794|passage=The duet was in '''alt'''; one stormed, the other half crying, half scolding, made up in volubility what her aunt possessed in authority, and it was not 'till Lady Meredith had twice raised her mild voice, either party could be silenced.}} #* {{quote-book|en|title=Helen and Olga: a Russian tale|page=194|author=Anne Manning|year=1857|passage=And he began, ‚Äî "Poor insect! born to flutter and to die;" ‚Äî falling into the second, directly Helen took the first, till he got down to such unreasonable bass that he suddenly gave a shriek in '''alt''' that made Olga stop her ears.}} # {{lb|en|now|archaic}} A state of excitement, a heightened emotional condition. {{defdate|from 18th c.}} #* {{quote-book|en|title=The History of Clarissa Harlowe: In a Series of Letters|author=[[w:Samuel Richardson|Samuel Richardson]]|year=1748|passage=I was, however, glad at my heart, that Mrs. Moore came up so seasonably with notice, that dinner was ready. The fair fugitive was all in '''alt'''. She had the game in her own hands; and by giving me so good an excuse for withdrawing, I had time to strengthen myself; the Captain had time to come; and the Lady to cool.}} #* {{quote-book|en|year=c. 1875|title=The Dodd Family Abroad|author=[[w:Charles James Lever|Charles James Lever]]|passage="Not," added she, as her eyes glittered with anger, and she sidled near the door for an exit‚Äî" not but, in the estimation of others, you may be quite an Adonis‚Äîa young gentleman of wit and fashion ‚Äîa beau of the first water; I have no doubt Mary Jane thinks so‚Äî you old wretch!" This, in '''alt''', and a bang of the door that brought down an oil picture that hung over it, closed the scene.}} #* {{quote-book|en|title=Tales: now first collected|page=113|author=Douglas William Jerrold|year=1891|passage=He had no wish to pry or listen; but if people would talk in '''alt''', whilst he moved, like a mole, about his business, family matters would cleave the ear which, however it tried, could not be deaf.}} #* {{quote-book|en|title=The Marrying Maid|author=[[w:Jo Beverly|Jo Beverly]]|page=50|in=Songs of Love and Death: All-Original Tales of Star-Crossed Love|year=2011|passage= That lady was in '''alt''' at Loxsleigh's high station and had spent the morning making inquiries of her friends, which also allowed her to spread the word about her interesting new acquaintance.|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=18IzT3qbheIC&pg=PA50&dq=%22That+lady+was+in+alt+at+Loxsleigh%E2%80%99s+high+station%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=E1X4T6CZAsql6wGOpInuBg&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22That%20lady%20was%20in%20alt%20at%20Loxsleigh%E2%80%99s%20high%20station%22&f=false}} ===Etymology 2=== Abbreviations. ====Adjective==== {{en-adj|-}} # {{abbreviation of|en|alternate}} # {{abbreviation of|en|alternative}}, especially as a cultural phenomenon seen as being outside the mainstream of its genre. #: ''alt-rock, alt-country, [[alt-right]], alt medicine'' #* {{seeCites|en}} ====Noun==== {{en-noun}} # {{abbreviation of|en|altitude}} # {{lb|en|Internet|gaming}} An [[alternate]] or [[secondary]] [[character]]. #* '''1996''', "Jonobie D. Baker", ''Survey of MUSHers.'' (on newsgroup ''rec.games.mud.tiny'') #*: Of these '''alts''', how many of them are a gender other than your own? #* '''2000''', "KaVir", ''Code Bases - why release buggy crap?'' (on newsgroup ''alt.mud'') #*: Yes, I have many '''alts''', and no, none of the others have any unusual capitalisation. ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=alt|ATL|Atl.|LAT|LTA|Lat.|TLA|Tal|lat|lat.}} ---- ==Catalan== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|ca|pro|-}}, from {{inh|ca|la|altus}}, ultimately of {{der|ca|ine-pro|-}} origin. ===Pronunciation=== * {{ca-IPA}} * {{rhymes|ca|alt}} ===Adjective=== {{ca-adj}} # [[high]] #: {{ant|ca|baix}} # [[tall]] #: {{ant|ca|baix}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|ca|altament}} * {{l|ca|alt√†ria}} * {{l|ca|altesa}} * {{l|ca|daltabaix}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|ca|al√ßar}} * {{l|ca|altitud}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:IEC2}} * {{R:GDLC}} * {{R:DNV}} * {{R:DCVB}} ---- ==Central Franconian== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|gmw-cfr|goh||ald}}, northern variant of {{m|goh|alt}}. The variation between the stems ''alt'' and ''aal'' is due to the development ''-ald-'' ‚Üí ''-ƒÅl-'', which occurred only in open syllables. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|gmw-cfr|/alt/}} ===Adjective=== {{head|gmw-cfr|adjective|masculine|aale|feminine|aal|comparative|aaler|or|√§√§ler|or|√§lder|superlative|aalste|or|√§√§lste|or|√§ltste}} # {{lb|gmw-cfr|most dialects}} [[old]] #: {{ux|gmw-cfr|Von '''aale''' L√∂ck ka‚Äô mer noch jet liehre.|There‚Äôs something to be learnt from '''old''' people.}} #: {{ux|gmw-cfr|Dat '''alt''' Huus m√∂t mer ens renoviere.|That '''old''' house should be renovated sometime.}} ====Usage notes==== * The commoner comparation forms were originally ''aaler, et aalste''. Today, those with umlaut are preferred due to influence of German {{m|de|√§lter}}, ''am'' {{m|de|√§ltesten}}. ====Related terms==== * {{l|gmw-cfr|Eldere}} ---- ==Cimbrian== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|cim|gmh|alt}}, from {{inh|cim|goh|alt}}, from {{inh|cim|gem-pro|*aldaz}}.
